DOC.HEAD: Judge Puts Off Hearing on Unsealing Court Documents
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday put off a hearing on Mobil Oil Corp.'s request to keep under seal environmental documents filed in a lawsuit brought by a former executive, who says he was fired for refusing to ``sanitize'' pollution reports. U.S. District Judge Harold A. Ackerman said he wanted to give Mobil's attorneys a chance to prepare arguments for their opposition to a request by The Associated Press to enter the case. Ackerman was to hear arguments Wednesday on whether or not to make the documents public. Stephen Wiley, an attorney for the former employee, said he favors unsealing the documents because they are ``directly relevant'' to a public proceeding. An attorney for the AP, Richard Eittreim, said his arguments were similar to Wiley's. But Mobil attorney Ron Green said he wanted to respond to the AP's legal papers, which he received shortly before the hearing. Ackerman set a new date for Friday and told the parties to submit more papers. The former employee, Valcar Bowman Jr., claims he was fired as Mobil Chemical Co.'s environmental affairs manager for refusing to ``sanitize'' assessments of environmental problems at company plants nationwide. He claims the company's legal office made changes to downplay pollution problems. Bowman, 47, of Riverdale, Ga., worked at the Princeton offices of Mobil. Mobil denies the charge, saying it had a right to fire Bowman and did so as part of a legitimate economic cutback. The company also denies altering the reports other than to make a few minor editing and typographical changes. The parties dispute whether Ackerman should unseal a series of environmental assessment reports submitted in support of arguments made in the pre-trial stages. Wiley says the whole documents are central to his case. Mobil says it is willing to release only portions it feels are relevant, and to release the entire reports _ which are self-critical evaluations _ would stifle attempts by companies to be candid about conditions at their plants.
